edu.berkeley.compbio.sequtils.strings
Interface SequenceSpectrum<T extends SequenceSpectrum>

All Superinterfaces:
edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.AdditiveClusterable<T>, Cloneable, edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.Clusterable<T>, com.davidsoergel.dsutils.GenericFactoryAware, com.davidsoergel.dsutils.Labellable<String>
All Known Implementing Classes:
DoubleKcount, HierarchicalSpectrum, IntKcount, Kcount, MarkovTreeNode, RonPSA, RonPSANode, RonPST
public interface SequenceSpectrum<T extends SequenceSpectrum>
extends edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.AdditiveClusterable<T>, Cloneable, com.davidsoergel.dsutils.GenericFactoryAware

Represents a statistical model of a sequence of bytes. The generic type tells what other kinds of SequenceSpectrum classes this one is compatible with under addition; frequently this is just the implementation class itself, but it may also be a superclass or interface that is compatible under addition via AdditiveClusterable. The fact that this class extends AdditiveClusterable expresses the requirement that there be a sensible (i.e., commutative and associative) "addition" operation on these models, given by AdditiveClusterable.plus(edu.berkeley.compbio.ml.cluster.AdditiveClusterable).

Version:
$Id
Author:
David Soergel

                              byte[] prefix)
                              throws SequenceSpectrumException
Computes the conditional probability of generating a symbol given a prefix under the model.

Parameters:
sigma - a byte specifying the symbol whose probability is to be computed
prefix - a byte array providing the conditioning prefix
Returns:
the conditional probability, a double value between 0 and 1, inclusive
Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException - when anything goes wrong
See Also:

fragmentLogProbability

double fragmentLogProbability(SequenceFragment sequenceFragment,
                              boolean perSample)
                              throws SequenceSpectrumException
Computes the total log probability of generating the given sequence fragment under the model. This differs from totalProbability(byte[]) in that the sequence fragment is not given explicitly but only as metadata. Thus its probability may be computed from summary statistics that are already available in the given SequenceFragment rather than from the raw sequence. Also, because these probabilities are typically very small, the result is returned in log space (indeed implementations will likely compute them in log space).

Parameters:
sequenceFragment - the SequenceFragment whose probability is to be computed
perSample - normalize the probability by the number of samples found in the SequenceFragment, i.e., take the geometric mean
Returns:
the natural logarithm of the conditional probability (a double value between 0 and 1, inclusive)
Throws:
SequenceSpectrumException

getAlphabet

byte[] getAlphabet()
Returns the alphabet of this SequenceSpectrum object.

Returns:
the alphabet (type byte[]) of this SequenceSpectrum object.

getMaxDepth

int getMaxDepth()
Returns the maximum length of substrings considered in computing this statistical model of the sequence. Our implicit assumption is that the sequences being modeled have some correlation length, and thus that statistical models of them can be built from substrings up to that length. Thus, this method tells the maximum correlation length provided by the model. A manifestation of this is that conditional probabilities of symbols given a prefix will cease to change as the prefix is lengthened (to the left) past this length.

Returns:
the maximum correlation length considered in the model.

getOriginalSequenceLength

long getOriginalSequenceLength()
Returns the length of the sequence that was scanned to produce this spectrum. This number may be greater than that given by #getNumberOfSamples() because every symbol is not necessarily counted as a sample, depending on the implementation.

Returns:
the length (type int) of this Kcount object.
See Also:
#addUnknown()

setIgnoreEdges

void setIgnoreEdges(boolean b)
Specify whether or not this sequence spectrum attempts to account for edge effects, i.e. the first and last words of each sequence. Accounting for these properly introduces a good deal of complexity and requires extra time, so considering spectra to describe biases is infinitely long sequn

Parameters:
b - the ignoreEdges
See Also:
FirstWordProvider

setImmutable

void setImmutable()
Declare that this spectrum should not change anymore. In practice this is not enforced; this is used only to free up memory by forgetting data that would be needed to recompute the spectrum if it were to change.

spectrumEquals

boolean spectrumEquals(SequenceSpectrum spectrum)
Test whether the given sequence statistics are equivalent to this one. Differs from equals() in that implementations of this interface may contain additional state which make them not strictly equal; here we're only interested in whether they're equal as far as this interface is concerned.

Naive implementations will simply test for exact equality; more sophisticated implementations ought to use a more rigorous idea of "statistically equivalent", though in that case we'll probabably need to provide more parameters, such as a p-value threshold to use. Note that the spectra know the number of samples used to generate them, so at least that's covered.

Parameters:
spectrum - the SequenceSpectrum to compare
Returns:
True if the spectra are equivalent, false otherwise
